lines.text: Newspapers can't compete in reporting what happened any more, but they can and should tell the public why it happened.
How could you give up a real newspaper job for teaching?
Well, that's a very good question, Mr. Gallagher. Maybe for the same reason that occasionally a musician wants to be a conductor, he wants to hear a hundred people play music the way he hears it.
I can drink any amount of alcohol I like and it doesn't bother me a bit.
Well it doesn't bither me a bot either!

[referring to Dr. Pine, Prof. Stone's boyfriend]
So he's got more degrees than a thermometer, so he speaks seven languages, so he's read every book. So what? The important thing is he's had no experience. He didn't start at the bottom and work up. That's the only way you can learn.
You're so right, Jim-zee. Take me. Where would I be if I just read books?
As my father used to say, a reporter has to do a lot of sweating before he earns the right to perspire.
Jimsy, what's a psychologist?
A guy who gives all kinds of advice about things he knows nothing about.
Morning. Hangover?
Calling what I have a 'hangover' is like referring to the Johnstown flood as a slight drizzle.
To me, journalism is, ah, like a hangover. You can read about it for years, but until you've actually experienced it, you have no conception of what it's really like.

[while reading the Eureka Bulletin]
Joel Barlow Stone. I'm sorry, but you stink!

[providing an impromptu lesson to Barney]
By the way, you heard about it, didn't you?
What?
Found him dead.
Who?
Boss.
No kidding. When?
Two minutes ago.
Where did they find him?
In his office.
What did happen?
Some dame shot him.
Some dame sho... Why?
who, what, where, when, how, and why. That's what every news story should answer.

[after being paged to Gannon's desk]
Yup?
press conference. Got some visiting firemen from Russia. Grab a cameraman, I told them we'd be right over.
[hands Gartner slip of paper]
Okay.
[turns to walk away, notices paper is not the intended address, but a flattering sketch of Erica Stone]
What's the matter?

[chuckling, hands back sketch]
Well, that's one way to end the Cold War.
[Gannon sees his error, snatches sketch back in embarrassment]
